node.title: Alice Sebold's book Lucky shot her to stardom, while a man sat in prison. Now his conviction has been overturned
node.alt: Author Alice Sebold speaks at the Sunday Book and Author Breakfast at BookExpo America.
node.description: Exploring Alice Sebold's experience of being raped and beaten by a stranger when she was a student at Syracuse University, Lucky went on to sell more than a million copies, while Anthony Broadwater – the man at the centre of the story – sat in prison for 16 years.
node.content:
["Author Alice Sebold has issued a public apology, and Netflix has reportedly scrapped plans to adapt her 1999 memoir Lucky, after the man she accused of raping her had his conviction overturned.\u00a0", "Exploring Sebold's experience of being attacked and beaten by a stranger\u00a0when she was a student at Syracuse University in the early 1980s, Lucky\u00a0went on to sell more than a million copies, while Anthony Broadwater \u2013 the man at the centre of the story \u2013 languished in prison for 16 years.", "The Lovely Bones author says she is now struggling with the role she played \"within a system that sent an innocent man to jail\", after prosecutors re-examining the case determined there were serious flaws in Mr Broadwater's arrest and trial.", "", "
Anthony Broadwater (centre) appears after a judge overturned his conviction that wrongfully put him in state prison.(AP via The Post Standard: Katrina Tulloch)
", "\"And certainly not to forever, and irreparably, alter a young man\u2019s life by the very crime that had altered mine.\"", "
Why was Broadwater convicted in the first place?
", "Published in 1999, the memoir's title\u00a0itself was inspired by a conversation with a police officer who told Sebold she was \"lucky\" she hadn't been killed during the ordeal.", "Months after the attack, she wrote of spotting a black man in the street who she believed to be her attacker.", "", "
Published in 1999, the memoir's title itself was inspired by a conversation with a police officer who told Sebold she was \"lucky\" she hadn't been killed.(GoodReads)
", "Sebold, who is white, went to police, and an officer concluded the man must have been Mr Broadwater, who had reportedly been seen in the area.", "After he was arrested, Sebold failed to identify him in a police line-up, picking a different man as her attacker because she was frightened of \u201cthe expression in his eyes\".", "But prosecutors put Mr Broadwater on trial anyway. He was convicted and served 16 years based largely on Sebold identifying him as her rapist on the witness stand and testimony that microscopic hair analysis had tied him to the crime.", "That type of analysis has since been deemed junk science by the US\u00a0Department of Justice.", "Because he refused to admit to the crime, Mr Broadwater was denied parole five times, before being released in 1998\u00a0\u2013 about one year before Lucky would be published.", "
Why did it take 40 years for mistakes\u00a0to come to light?
", "A planned Netflix adaptation of Lucky reportedly helped sow the seeds of doubt around Mr Broadwater's conviction.", "Executive producer Timothy Mucciante had been working\u00a0on the project this year when he began to notice discrepancies between the memoir and the script.", "\u201cI started having some doubts, not about the story that Alice told about her assault, which was tragic, but the second part of her book about the trial, which didn\u2019t hang together,\u201d Mr\u00a0Mucciante told the New York Times.", "Convinced of Mr Broadwater's innocence, Mr Mucciante left the production in June and hired a private investigator to review the case.", "At the investigator's suggestion, they collated the evidence and gave it to defence lawyer David Hammond, who Mr Broadwater had hired \"around the same time\",\u00a0based on the recommendation of another local lawyer.", "
Case marred by 'prosecutorial misconduct' and mistaken ID\u00a0
", "In their motion to have Mr Broadwater's conviction vacated, Mr Hammond and fellow defence lawyer Melissa Swartz argued that the case had relied solely on Sebold's courtroom identification and a \"now-discredited method of microscopic hair analysis\".", "They also alleged prosecutorial misconduct was a factor during the police line-up, suggesting the prosecutor had falsely\u00a0told Sebold that Mr Broadwater and the man next to him were known to one another and had set out to try to trick her.", "Evidently, the New York State Supreme Court agreed, moving to vacate the rape conviction and other counts related to it.", "\"That doesn't cut it. This should never have happened.\"", "
What has Alice Sebold said?
", "In response to the development, Sebold released a statement apologising to Mr Broadwater \"for the fact that the life you could have led was unjustly robbed from you\".", "\"I will forever be sorry for what was done to him.\"", "", "
Alice Sebold issued a statement, apologising for her role in Mr Broadwater's conviction.(Medium)
", "Adding that she would \"continue to struggle with the role that I unwittingly played within a system that sent an innocent man to jail\", Sebold said she would \"also grapple with the fact that my rapist will, in all likelihood, never be known\".", "\"[They] may have gone on to rape other women, and certainly will never serve the time in prison that Mr\u00a0Broadwater did.\"", "According to Variety, a Netflix adaptation of Lucky \u2014 which had been set to star You\u00a0actress Victoria Pedretti \u2014 was\u00a0abandoned after losing its financing \"months ago\".", "A spokesperson for Scribner, Sebold\u2019s publisher, told The Guardian that \u201cScribner has no plans to update the text of Lucky at this time\".", "
How has Broadwater responded?
", "Mr Broadwater broke down when the judge announced his decision, describing how the conviction \u2014 and a requirement to remain on the sex offenders registry \u2014 had ruined his life.", "\"When the District-Attorney spoke to me, his words were so profound \u2014\u00a0so strong \u2014\u00a0it shook me,\" Mr Broadwater told CNN.", "", "
Anthony Broadwater broke down crying when the convictions were overturned.(AP via The Post Standard:\u00a0Katrina Tulloch)
", "Mr Broadwater's lawyer Melissa Swartz\u00a0said he had no comment on Sebold's statement.", "But he had earlier told the New York Times he hoped the author would come forward and apologise.", "\"I just hope and pray that maybe Ms\u00a0Sebold will come forward and say, \u2018Hey, I made a grave mistake,\u2019 and give me an apology,\" he said.", "\"I sympathise with her, but she was wrong.\"", "ABC/AP"]
